frameDefinitions: An Agent causes a Theme to move from a Source, along a Path, to a Goal.
In this frame a Patient undergoes a change of phase.
An Entity loses moisture with the outcome of being in a dry state.
In this frame a Patient changes its consistency.
In this frame a Patient is in a phase brought about after a change of phase.
An Entity changes from a Prior_state to a Post_state in a sequence that follows a pre-defined plan, expectation, or model of change.
frameExamples: She <t>threw</t> her shoes into the dryer .
Collect up the  <t>thawed</t> water from the freezer section.
Their offensive armament has <t>developed</t> from short range missiles to long-range ballistic weaponry in a relatively short period .
listRoleDefinitions: The <fen>Agent</fen> is the one whose action causes the motion of a <fen>Theme</fen>.  The <fen>Agent</fen> is generally realized as the External Argument.
The role <fen>Theme</fen> is generally an NP Object.
The role <fen>Source</fen> is the starting point of motion.
The role <fen>Path</fen> is any description of a trajectory of motion which is neither a <fen>Source</fen> nor <fen>Goal</fen>.
The role <fen>Goal</fen> is the point at which the <fen>Theme</fen> ends up as a result of the motion.

The role <fen>Area</fen> is used for expressions which describe a general area in which motion takes place when the motion is understood to be irregular or not to consist of a single, linear path. Locative setting adjuncts may also be assigned this frame element.
<fen>Cause</fen> marks expressions that indicate some non-intentional, typically non-human, force that causes the <fen>Theme</fen> to be set in motion.
A resultant state that the <fen>Theme</fen> is in at the end of its motion.
A previous state that the <fen>Theme</fen> was in before the beginning of its motion.
The time at which the motion of the <fen>Theme</fen> occurs.
The <fen>Place</fen> is the general area that provides a setting for a specific motion (with <fen>Source</fen>, <fen>Path</fen>, or <fen>Goal</fen>).
<fen>Patient</fen> is the entity that undergoes a change of phase.
This role identifies the <fen>Time</fen> at which the <fen>Patient</fen> changes phase.
Where the <fen>Patient</fen> changes phase.
The <fen>Entity</fen> is the thing that loses moisture and becomes dry.
When the <fen>Entity</fen> becomes dry.
The location where the <fen>Entity</fen> becomes dry.
<fen>Patient</fen> is the entity that undergoes a change.
When the <fen>Patient</fen> changes consistency.
Where the the <fen>Patient</fen> changes consistency.
The <fen>Substance</fen> is the entity which has had its phase altered.
The object that undergoes change.
The time at which the progress occurs.
The location where the Progress occurs.
listRoleExamples: <fex>Pat</fex> threw the china at the wall.
Pat threw <fex>the china</fex> at the wall.
Pat dragged the box <fex>out of the cupboard</fex>.
I pushed the trolley <fex>along the street</fex>.
Kim threw the cat <fex>into the garden</fex>.
Kim pushed the lawnmower <fex>around the garden</fex>.
<fex>The storm</fex> tossed the sailor from the boat
The fireman dragged the injured driver <fex>clear</fex>
Paul pulled Fran upright <fex>from her sitting position</fex>.
We shoved half of the cargo overboard <fex>on the 29th</fex>.
Advances <fex>in marketing techniques</fex> have since rendered it obsolete.
<fex>When</fex> did the X-wing progress beyond the drawing board?
